title:
A Methodology for Gradual Semantics for
Structured Argumentation under Incomplete Information
abstract:
Gradual semantics have demonstrated great potential in ar-
gumentation, in particular for deploying quantitative bipo-
lar argumentation frameworks (QBAFs) in a number of real-
world settings, from judgmental forecasting to explainable
AI. In this paper, we provide a novel methodology for obtain-
ing gradual semantics for structured argumentation frame-
works, where the building blocks of arguments and rela-
tions between them are known, unlike in QBAFs, where ar-
guments are abstract entities. Differently from existing ap-
proaches, our methodology accommodates incomplete infor-
mation about arguments' premises. We demonstrate the po-
tential of our approach by introducing two different instan-
tiations of the methodology, leveraging existing gradual se-
mantics for QBAFs in these more complex frameworks. We
also define a set of novel properties for gradual semantics in
structured argumentation, discuss their suitability over a set
of existing properties. Finally, we provide a comprehensive
theoretical analysis assessing the instantiations, demonstrat-ing the their advantages over existing gradual semantics for
QBAFs and structured argumentation.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content:
Argumentation frameworks have emerged as powerful tools
for reasoning about conflicting information and making de-
cisions in complex environments (see (Baroni et al. 2018;
Atkinson et al. 2017) for overviews). In recent years, grad-
ual semantics have shown great promise in extending these
frameworks, particularly in the realm of quantitative bipo-
lar argumentation frameworks (QBAFs) (Baroni, Rago, and
Toni 2018), where arguments have weights and they include
two relations of attack and support. Such bipolar approaches
thus allow for both negative and positive, respectively, in-
fluences between arguments to be accounted for, arguably
aligning more closely with human judgment (Polberg and
Hunter 2018). Gradual semantics have found applications
in diverse (and often human-centric) areas, from judgmen-
tal forecasting (Irwin, Rago, and Toni 2022) to explainable
AI (Vassiliades, Bassiliades, and Patkos 2021; Cyras et al.
2021; Guo et al. 2023), by allowing for quantitative, and
thus in some cases more nuanced, evaluations of arguments
beyond the traditional accept/reject dichotomy. These quan-
titative strengths can be particularly useful in cases where
the information in argumentation framework is incomplete,
since this uncertainty can be accounted for quantitatively.
However, most of the existing work on gradual semantics
(see (Baroni, Rago, and Toni 2019) for an overview) has fo-
cused on formalisms based on the abstract argumentation
framework by Dung (1995), where arguments are treated
as atomic entities without internal structure. This abstrac-
tion, while useful in many contexts, fails to capture the rich
logical structure that is often present in real-world argu-
ments. Meanwhile, various forms of structured argumenta-
tion frameworks (see (Besnard et al. 2014) for an overview),
which explicitly represent the internal composition of argu-
ments and the relationships between their components, may
offer a more expressive and realistic model in agent-based
domains, such as user modeling (Hadoux, Hunter, and Pol-
berg 2023), scientific debates (Cramer and Dauphin 2020),
and model reconciliation settings (Sreedharan, Chakraborti,
and Kambhampati 2021; Vasileiou et al. 2024). However,
this greater reliance on the logical (e.g., background or
contextual) knowledge can lead to more problematic cases
where this information is incomplete. Yet, the development
of gradual semantics for structured argumentation has re-
ceived little attention to date.
A notable exception is the gradual semantics proposed by
Jedwabny, Croitoru, and Bisquert (2020), which provides a
method for assigning gradual evaluations to structured ar-
guments. This approach uses T-norms and T-conorms from
the area of fuzzy logic to aggregate the strengths of an argu-
ment's components, offering a way to evaluate structured ar-
guments quantitatively. However, this semantics again faces
challenges when dealing with incomplete information since
it relies on an assumption of complete knowledge and pres-
ence of an argument's supporting elements. This require-
ment can limit its applicability in real-world scenarios,
where such information is almost always incomplete.
To address these limitations, we introduce a novel
methodology for constructing gradual semantics for struc-
tured argumentation frameworks that naturally accommo-
dates incomplete information. Our approach is modular in
that it allows for different gradual semantics to be instan-
tiated based on the requirements of a given task and con-
text. Namely, we permit arguments as chosen forms of state-
ments in statement graphs (Hecham, Bisquert, and Croitoru
2018), consisting of a premise (a compound of literals) and

sections.title: Preliminaries
sections.content:
a claim (a literal). Then, a core tenet of our approach is the
selection of an existing gradual semantics for abstract ar-
gumentation, which is used to dialectically evaluate the lit-
erals in a premise, based on their attacking and supporting
evidence, before these “intermediate” evaluations are aggre-
gated, depending on the statement's construction, to give a
final strength for the statement.
Our methodology combines the expressiveness of struc-
tured argumentation with the flexibility of gradual se-
mantics, accounting for the practical reality of incomplete
knowledge. It thus provides a novel paradigm for leverag-
ing the potential of existing gradual semantics in structured
argumentation.
The main contributions of this paper are as follows:
• We introduce a novel methodology for constructing grad-
ual semantics in structured argumentation frameworks
with incomplete information, presenting two specific in-
stantiations based on different existing gradual seman-
tics.
• We present a collection of novel and existing (Jedwabny,
Croitoru, and Bisquert 2020) properties for gradual se-
mantics in structured argumentation and discuss their
suitability in different settings.
• Using these properties, we conduct a comprehensive the-
orical analysis of our two proposed instantiations, two
different instantiations of the T-norm semantics (Jed-
wabny, Croitoru, and Bisquert 2020) and two exist-
ing gradual semantics for QBAFs, demonstrating the
strengths and limitations of each approach.
Statement Graphs
We consider a propositional language L comprising a finite
set of atoms, including a special atom T to represent truth. A
literal is an atom ф or its negation ¬ф. Note that ¬(¬ф) ≡ ф.
A compound is an expression constructed from literals using
connectives ^ and v.
A defeasible rule r is of the form Φ ⇒ Ψ, where Φ is
a consistent compound (e.g., with no atom and its nega-
tion) and Ψ is a literal. We call Φ the body and Ψ the head
of the rule (denoted Body(r) and Head(r), respectively).
Pragmatically, defeasible rules represent tentative informa-
tion that may be applied if uncontested. A rule r is a fact
rule if Body(r) = Т.
A knowledge base is a tuple K = (Rf, Rn), with Rf a set
of fact rules and Rn a set of non-fact rules.
In this work, we view a knowledge base K as a learned
repository of statements.

sections.title: Definition 1 (Statement)
sections.content:
Let K = (Rf,Rn) be a knowl-
edge base. We say that a = (Φ, Ψ) is a statement from K if
∃r ∈ Rf ∪ Rn such that Φ = Body(r) and Ψ = Head(r).
We refer to Φ as the premise and to Ψ as the claim of the
statement. We define Prem(a) = {x | x ∈ Φ} \ {T} as the
set of literals comprising the premise of the statement a.
Note that if the premise of a statement a is T then
Prem(a) = Ø.

sections.title: Definition 2 (Attack and Support)
sections.content:
Let α₁ = (Φ₁, Ψ₁) and
α₂ = (Φ₂, Ψ₂) be two statements. We say that:
•
α₁ supports α₂ iff Ψ₁ ∈ Prem(α₂);
•
α₁ attacks α₂ iff ¬Ψ₁ ∈ Prem(α₂).
Given a knowledge base K, we generate a statement graph
structured with respect to the support and attack relations
between statements, as in the work by Hecham, Bisquert,
and Croitoru (2018) and Jedwabny, Croitoru, and Bisquert
(2020). However, differently to their work, we include the
quantitative weights of each statement within the statement
graph, rather than applying them separately. This refor-
mulation allows for direct comparisons with properties of
QBAFs (Baroni, Rago, and Toni 2019), which provided in-
spiration for our properties.

sections.title: Definition 3 (Statement Graph)
sections.content:
A statement graph is a
quadruple (X, A,S,τ) such that:
• X is a set of statements;
• A ⊆ X × X is an attack relation such that ∀α₁,α₂ ∈ X,
(α₁,α₂) ∈ A iff α₁ attacks α₂;
• S ⊆ X × X is a support relation such that ∀α₁, α₂ ∈ X,
(α₁,α₂) ∈ S iff α₁ supports α₂;
• τ: X → [0,1] is a weight over the statements.
For any α₁ ∈ X, we call A(α₁) = {α₂ ∈ Χ | (α₂, α₁) ∈ Α}
the attackers of α₁ and S(α₁) = {α₂ ∈ Χ | (α₂,α₁) ∈ S} the
supporters of α₁. We say that a statement graph (X,A,S,τ)
represents some knowledge base K = (Rf, Rn) if ∀r∈ RfU
Rn, ∃α ∈ X, where α = (Φ, Ψ), such that Φ = Body(r) and
Ψ = Head(r).

sections.title: Corollary 1
sections.content:
Given a statement graph (X,A,S,τ), A ∩ S =
Ø.
A statement graph thus gives a restricted form of struc-
tured argumentation framework with conjunctive premises,
undercutting attacks, deductive/evidential supports and ar-
gument weights.

sections.title: Example 1
sections.content:
Consider the knowledge base K = {{T ⇒
a, Т ⇒ b}, {a^ b ⇒ d, f → ¬a}}, where:
The proofs for all the theoretical work we have undertaken are
given in the appendix.

sections.title: Gradual Semantics
sections.content:
• a: "CO2 emissions are rising"
• b: “Global temperatures are increasing"
• d: "Climate change is human-caused"
• f: “CO2 measurements are unreliable"
Figure 1 gives a statement graph representing K, with arbi-
trary weights assigned to statements. This statement graph
will serve as a running example in the subsequent sections
(where additional literals and statements will come into
play).
For the remainder of the paper, we assume, as given,
a generic statement graph W = (X,A,S,τ). We also re-
strict statement graphs to acyclic graphs in line with recent
works (de Tarlé, Bonzon, and Maudet 2022; Rago, Li, and
Toni 2023).

sections.title: Definition 4 (Gradual Semantics)
sections.content:
A gradual semantics σ:
X → [0,1] assigns each statement α ∈ X a strength
σω(α) ∈ [0,1].
In essence, gradual semantics offer a principled approach
to evaluating statements quantitatively, i.e., for assigning ar-
guments an acceptance on a gradual scale. In this paper, we
refer to any argument a∈ X with: σ(α) =1 as accepted, and
σ(α) =0 as rejected.
Next, we define two notions for the gradual semantics
of (Jedwabny, Croitoru, and Bisquert 2020).

sections.title: Definition 5
sections.content:
A complete support tree (CST) for some α₁ ∈
X is a set of statements T ⊆ X s.t.:
•
α₁ ∈ T;
• ∀α₂ ∈ Τ, ∀x ∈ Prem(α₂), ∃α₃ = (Φ₃, Ψ₃) ∈ T s.t.
Φ₃ = x;
• ∀α₂,α₃ ∈ T s.t. (α₂, α₃) ∈ Α;
• T' ⊂ T s.t. T' is a CST for α₁ (minimality wrt set inclu-
sion).
We denote with TW(α₁) the set of CSTs for α₁ wrt W.
Moreover, given two CSTs T ∈ TW (α₁) and T' ∈ TW (α₂)
for Α₁, Α₂ ∈ X, respectively, Tattacks T' iff ∃α₃ ∈ T' s.t.
(α₁, α₃) ∈ Α.

sections.title: Definition 6 (De Morgan Triple)
sections.content:
A triple (⊗, ⊕, ¬), where
⊗ is a T-norm, ⊕ is a T-conorm, and ¬ is a negation, is
called a De Morgan triple iff ∀v₁, v₂ ∈ [0,1], (v₁,v₂) =
¬(⊕(¬(v₁),¬(v₂)), and ⊕(v₁, v₂) = ¬(⊗(¬(v₁), ¬(v₂)).

sections.title: Definition 7 (T-norm Semantics)
sections.content:
Given a De Morgan
triple (⊗,⊕, ¬), the T-norm semantics σΤ is a structured
gradual semantics s.t. for any α ∈ X:
\σ_Τ^W(α) = ⊕_(T∈T_W (α)) ⊗(T)
\otimes(T) = ⊗_(α∈T) τ(α) ⊗ ¬(⊕_(T'∈T_W(α'∈X), T' attacks T) I(T'))
\I(T') = τ(α)
α∈T

sections.title: Definition 8 (DF-QuAD Semantics)
sections.content:
The DF-QuAD se-
mantics σδ is an abstract gradual semantics s.t. for any
α∈Χ:
\σ_δ^W(α) = c(τ(α), Σ(σ_δ^W(A(α))), Σ(σ_δ^W(S(α))))
where, for any S ⊆ X, σ(S) = (σ(α₁),...,σ(ακ))
for (α₁,..., ακ), an arbitrary permutation of S, and:
• Σ is s.t. Σ(()) = 0 and, for v1, ..., vn ∈ [0, 1] (n ≥ 1), if
n = 1, then ∑((v1)) = v1; if n = 2, then ∑((v1, v2)) =
v1 + v2 − v1 · v2; and if n > 2, then ∑((v1,...,vn)) =
Σ(Σ((v1,..., vn-1)), vn);
• c is s.t., for vº, υ¯, v⁺ ∈ [0,1], if v¯ > vt, then
c(vº, v¯, v+) = vº – vº. v+ − v¯| and if v¯ < v⁺, then
c(vº, v¯, v+) = vº + (1 − vº) • [v+ − v¯|.

sections.title: Definition 9 (QEM Semantics)
sections.content:
The QEM semantics σę is
an abstract gradual semantics s.t. for any α ∈ X:
\σ_ε^W(α) = τ(α) + (1 − τ(α)) · h(Eα) − τ(α)·h(-Eα)
where Ea = Σα+∈S(α) τ(α+) − Σα-∈A(α) τ(α-) and for
all v ∈ R, h(v) = max{v,0}2
1+max{v,0}2.

sections.title:
A Methodology for Structured Gradual
Semantics
sections.content:
In this section, we introduce a novel methodology for defin-
ing structured gradual semantics, leveraging abstract gradual
semantics, to evaluate the strength of statements in statement
graphs (§). We then redefine and discuss the suitability of ex-
isting properties for gradual semantics of statement graphs
(§), which motivates our introduction of novel properties (§),
before we evaluate our approach with both sets of properties,
comparing against existing structured and abstract gradual
semantics (§).
We describe a simplification of the original algorithm for the
case of acyclic graphs.

sections.title: Definition 10
sections.content:
Given an abstract gradual semantics σ∗, a
modular dialectical semantics supported by σ is a struc-
tured gradual semantics σμ s.t. for any α₁ ∈ X:
\σ_μ^W(α₁) = ⊕({σ_∗(x)|x ∈ Prem(α₁)})
where ⊕ : [0,1]* → [0,1] is a premise aggregation func-
tion and (with an abuse of notation) any x ∈ Prem(α₁) is
treated as a statement with some defined τ(x) and:
Α(x) = {(Φ₂, Ψ₂) | (Φ₂, Ψ₂) ∈ Α(α₁), ¬x∈Ψ₂}
S(x) = {(Φ₃, Ψ₃) | (Φ₃, Ψ₃) ∈ S(α₁), χ∈Ψ₃}
The intuition behind the modular dialectical semantics is
that the evidence supporting or attacking each literal in a
statement's premise can be evaluated dialectically via an ab-
stract gradual semantics, rather than based on the complete-
ness of its support as in the literature (Jedwabny, Croitoru,
and Bisquert 2020). Once the literals have such a dialecti-
cal strength, they are then evaluated as part of the premise
by the premise aggregation function. This permits the incor-
poration of incomplete information, since the evidence for
or against premises is combined dialectically starting from a
statement's weight, giving an approximation of the strength
of a statement based on the available evidence. Statements'
strengths are thus calculated recursively, as in abstract grad-
ual semantics. This modular methodology permits instanti-
ations tailored to individual applications based on chosen
configurations of the supporting abstract gradual semantics,
the definition of premises' weights and the premise aggrega-
tion function. In the following, we define one such instanti-
ation, tailored to our restrictions of the statement graphs of
Definition 3, where premises are conjunctions, with its sup-
porting abstract gradual semantics left unspecified.

sections.title: Definition 11
sections.content:
Given an abstract gradual semantics σ∗, the
dialectical conjunction (DC) semantics supported by σ∗, de-
noted by σ∧, is a modular dialectical semantics s.t., for any
α₁ ∈ X, if Prem(α₁) = Ø, then σW(α₁) = τ(α₁); other-
wise:
\σ_∧^W(α₁) = ×_(x∈Prem(α₁)) √τ(α₁)
n σ_∗^W(x)
where τ(x) = √τ(α₁) and n = |Prem(α₁)|.

sections.title: Example 2
sections.content:
Consider the statement graph from Example 1,
where S = {(α₂, α₁), (α₃,α₁)} and A = {(α₄, α₁)}. Here,
α₁ = (a^b,d) represents the statement “CO2 emissions
are rising and global temperatures are increasing, there-
fore climate change is human-caused." Given the DC se-
mantics supported by DF-QuAD, the strength of statement
α₁ is calculated as follows: σW(α₁) = σW(a) × σW(b) =
AD
0.916 × 0.957 = 0.877, where τ(a) = τ(b) = √0.8 = 0.894.
In contrast, the T-norm-p semantics produces a strength of:
σW(α₁) = τ(α₁)×τ(α₂)×τ(α₃) = 0.8 × 0.9 × 0.6 = 0.432.
Here, we see how the DC and T-norm-p semantics dif-
fer in their evaluation of statement a₁. The DC semantics
AD
p

sections.title: Definition 10 Given
sections.content:
A modular dialectical semantics is
that the evidence supporting or attacking each literal in a
statement’s premise can be evaluated dialectically via an ab-
stract gradual semantics, rather than based on the complete-
ness of its support as in the literature (Jedwabny, Croitoru,
and Bisquert 2020). Once the literals have such a dialecti-
cal strength, they are then evaluated as part of the premise
by the premise aggregation function. This permits the incor-
poration of incomplete information, since the evidence for
or against premises is combined dialectically starting from a
statement’s weight, giving an approximation of the strength
of a statement based on the available evidence. Statements’
strengths are thus calculated recursively, as in abstract grad-
ual semantics. This modular methodology permits instanti-
ations tailored to individual applications based on chosen
configurations of the supporting abstract gradual semantics,
the definition of premises’ weights and the premise aggrega-
tion function. In the following, we define one such instanti-
ation, tailored to our restrictions of the statement graphs of
Definition 3, where premises are conjunctions, with its sup-
porting abstract gradual semantics left unspecified.
